data.text: Using a Hybrid Bike for Touring
What are people's views on using a hybrid bike for Touring? I'm tempted to move to a gravel bike, but do like the position of a hybrid and can fit all my kit on my current bike.
Roll what‚Äôs best for you. I use a Surly Krampus and a Karate Monkey mt bikes for my trips.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: I tour on a 2014 Trek Hybrid.
data.author: John Edward Harris

data.text: My partner has a Trek fx2 hybrid, its so comfortable she tells me, just jad a upgrade on the rear cassette.
data.author: Graham Minshall

data.text: I use to ride an aluminum hybrid. Now I'm on a carbon gravel bike. I'm all about short 3 day max trips. Speed is important to me. Take that for what you will.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: Hybrids work great - especially if it fits you and you like it. No need for a different bike just because the gravel bikes are so popular
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: üëç
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: It's a personal preference. If you like the position the hybrid purs you in, then use it! I went through 2 different gravel bikes before going back to a hardtail mtb due to position.
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: üëçüëç
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: Thanks all...good to hear that there's a lot of you still using hybrids.
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: My two pennies. An upright riding position is what you want for touring - long or short. Saves your back, better off road, safer on descents and most of all you get to see the world you are travelling in! Hybrids have that nice upright position, fine as long you stick to road but gears and tyre width might let you down off road. All around ideal is an adventure bike with a tall stack, riser bars and 2 inch plus tyres.
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: What said!
data.author: Doug Yuill

data.text: Ride what works best for you.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Oh one last thing, hybrids are mostly flat bar. That's great for touring. TBH drops are really just for racing. Controversial! But try squeezing the brakes on drops, on your loaded bike, with freezing hands, on a rainy, foggy mountain descent on tour, and you'll see how wrong they are for touring. Again an alt or adventure bar is ideal. Jones, Moloko, etc.
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: Hybrids are fine, and don't let bicycle marketing tell you otherwise.
data.author: Greg Molnar

data.text: Giant Toughroad... üòÅüëç
data.author: Marty Donaldson
Peter Whillians

data.text: Forgive my ignorance but what is the difference between a hybrid and a gravel bike?Ôøº
data.author: Robert Loftin

data.text:
a hybrid is usually a general purpose bike with flat handlebars & medium width slightly knobby tires. Some have front shocks, though usually lighter shocks with far less travel than a MTB. Gravel bikes usually have drop bars, similar to a road bike, but a bit more flared at the sides, & the forks allow you to put wider, grippier tires on them than a road bike. More detail in the ‚Äòtypes of bikes‚Äô section on this link: https://bikepacking.com/bikepacking-101/
Bikepacking 101
bikepacking.com
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: thanks! Sounds like a hybrid could also be a gravel bike. I‚Äôve seen tons of flat bar bikes on the Divide.
data.author: Robert Loftin

data.text: Yes, the ‚Äòdivision‚Äô between different types of bikes is a bit blurry, though as other commenters have mentioned, hybrids usually use lower end components, while gravel bikes can be purchased with anything from lower end components to very high end, depending on what the purchaser wants &/or can afford.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: got it. Thanks.
data.author: Robert Loftin

data.text: Depends on the hybrid, the bigger the tires it can fit, the better off you will be. My wife's hybrid fits 29x2.1 and many 2.2 which opens up the options but also tends to make the bike more capable offroad. The other difference is that in general, gravel bikes....flatbar or dropbar tend to come with a better spec of components as they're seen as performance oriented bikes. There are high-end hybrids but they top out around 2k. Where obviously, gravel bikes can cost over 10k
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: You can use whatever kind of bike you want - pull it out of a dumpster, doesn't matter. Can it get you from A -> B and carry some stuff for you? Everything else is extra.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I‚Äôve ridden my hybrid, equipped with 38mm tires on a few multi-day rails to trails trips. It‚Äôs a 1x11 & doesn‚Äôt have the gearing to go up the really steep logging roads we sometimes encounter in BC though, & its tiny 20mm headset shock doesn‚Äôt handle rougher trails, though others had that same challenge on their gravel bikes. I‚Äôm also a road biker & I used to mountain bike, & found that I prefer the flat bars when I‚Äôm on trails. I have done pavement touring on a drop bar bike & liked that, though some of the trails I ride on are rough enough that I‚Äôve now outfitted a hardtail MTB for bikepacking, & I enjoy having proper front shocks for the rougher trails!
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Generally speaking, hybrids are a way to fill the void created by America‚Äôs tendency to see cycling as a sport only. Hybrids were created for utility use around town and for light recreation. Most of them are under $1000 and their quality will become obvious when you put them under significant stress (mountain biking, training for a century or a multi-day trip. That is to say, they might hold up, components tend to go quicker than the bicycle manufacturer‚Äôs respective parts. So check the components on your own rig before switching over to blacking/touring. I think upgrading to a decent gravel bike will have a lot of value for you. Their designed to take vibrations, many of them now come with mounting points for long haul gravel touring. Overall it will likely be a higher quality bike and it‚Äôs design will work for you.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Whatever you‚Äôre most comfortable is what you‚Äôre going to enjoy the most. Bikepacking is all about enjoyment.
data.author: Alex Young

data.text: Look for flat bar touring bike or trekking bikes, you may find a general commuter hybrid may not have low enough gearing or strong enough wheels. You may also find the frames flexes a lot with the weigh of panniers.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: The expedition bikes like Thorn etc are mostly flat bar bikes. Check out Oxford bike works as well if your looking for flat bar tourer/ trekking bikes.
data.author: Duncan Pringle

data.text: I have done several motel based tours on a 1995 Trek 750 hybrid. Perfect for 30-60 mile days. Very comfortable, great riding position for enjoying the world, easy maintenance, chromally steel frame is solid. Flat pedals.
data.author: Gary Bicycles

data.text: Trek dual sport loaded out. I think it works great.
data.author: Adam Fish
Adam Fish

data.text: I like the idea of front suspension on a hybrid, think that could work for me.
data.author: Channy Derry

data.text: My husband bike Trek Fx3 - he's loving it.
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: My bike. Resting in a motel today.
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: Works fine. Whyte Stirling and a combination of bikepacking and touring luggage.
data.author: Jon Mathias
